column1: There is no shame in poverty.  The shame is in greed.

Good progress thanks to worker movement. But for context this gives each frontline worker risking their lives just $300 extra.  Since pandemic began Jeff Bezos personally made $70 billion. Giving each worker an extra $1000 would cost a mere $2 billion. https://t.co/ZzHDMG5dlk

Stock market growth now is driven largely by stock buy-backs which keep money circulating among the already-wealthy. That’s what GOP $2 trillion tax scam did.   It’s not trickle-down economics it’s gush-up economics: take from working people & give to wealthiest.

As people support local shops on #SmallBusinessSaturday the government should too! We can do that by passing my Paycheck Recovery Act which sends grants directly to businesses to cover payroll rehire workers help with their operating expenses and withstand this crisis.

Perceived link b/w economy & market is pure nostalgia for time when employment & market had some connection & wealth inequality was better.   1962: 2 most highly valued companies employed nearly 1.2 mm workers.   2019: 2 most highly valued(Microsoft and Apple) employed 280000.

Repeat after me: the stock market is NOT the economy.  FACTS:  The wealthiest 10% of US households own 84% of value of stocks. The top 1% controls 40%.    The wellbeing of vast majority of Americans has nothing to do with stocks.

This exciting plan includes the Domestic Workers Bill of Rights that I introduced with Sen. Harris and my Biden-Sanders Unity Task Force agreement to create at least 600000 jobs in long-term supports and services. Good for seniors families and workers! https://t.co/YIBkDouP5x

As we honor tribes across WA on Native American Heritage Day let's also recommit to repairing the violence trauma and damage America continues to cause Indigenous folks. This is only underscored by a pandemic that is disproportionately harming Native and Indigenous people.
No. Just no. End the death penalty.  https://t.co/8UPYYmVelA
Grateful for the heroic frontline workers who are keeping our community and country going day after day. THANK YOU for all you do for all of us!

I'm grateful to represent you to fight for you and to be organizing alongside you as we work to deliver real change that makes all of our lives better. While it's a difficult time I hope today brings you joy a good meal and rest. Happy Thanksgiving from my family to yours! https://t.co/dDDOzz6oKw
Yep. Exactly. Cancel it. All of it. https://t.co/wmqUJwl1oj

Flynn pleaded guilty—not once but twice—to lying to federal investigators about contact with a foreign adversary.  This corrupt pardon is yet another abuse of power by a failed one-term president who undermines the rule of law the constitution and our democracy at every turn. https://t.co/x565CL5LP7

Vivek also understands clearly the social determinants of health and the ways in which government must step up to provide human services that allow for opportunity for everyone. And he would bring much needed representation of the AAPI community into the Cabinet.

One payment of $1200 was never going to be enough for someone to withstand this devastating crisis. It's time to send monthly relief checks to every person in this country during the pandemic.

Immigrants and the children of immigrants are resilient. We push boulders up mountains and succeed because we have to. That’s the kind of leadership we need—and that’s the kind of leadership VP Kamala Harris will bring to the White House.  My August OpEd: https://t.co/0vT6NjP62w

This legislation is a bold step towards justice and accountability. I'll fight to swiftly move it though Congress.   We need everyone across the country to continue building the public pressure necessary to get this approved by the House passed in the Senate and signed into law.

8⃣It works to END the militarization of law enforcement by restricting the program that allows military equipment to transfer to local departments.   It also requires federal state and local law enforcement to use existing federal funds to ensure the use of police body cameras.

7⃣It gives DOJ the power to subpoena law enforcement departments for pattern and practice investigations which allows them to hold accountable agencies who violate the constitution or other federal laws.   It also establishes a National Task Force on Law Enforcement Oversight.

6⃣This bill allows prosecutors to hold officers accountable for the deprivation of civil rights AND civil liberties by changing the mens rea requirement from “willful” to “knowingly or with reckless disregard”.   This improves accountability for police brutality and misconduct.

5⃣It requires the reporting of ALL incidents of use of force against a civilian to the Justice Department and mandates that demographic data and an explanation of the incident are included too.   It also collects data on law enforcement practices such as stops and searches.

4⃣It finally ends qualified immunity.   This ensures that we are able to hold accountable police officers and members of law enforcement who perpetrate violence murders and injustices—no matter what badge they wear.

3⃣It establishes a federal police misconduct registry that is public and tracks complaints at the local state and federal level.   This increases accountability and transparency while ensuring past misconduct can be detected when an officer is trying to transfer departments.

2⃣It finally classifies lynching as a federal hate crime in the United States. We know that this is long overdue but it is also urgently necessary today as we just witnessed the modern-day lynching of Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia.

1⃣It not only bans chokeholds like the one used to murder George Floyd but it establishes them as a civil rights violation too.   It also bans no-knock warrants for drug cases like the one that was used when officers murdered Breonna Taylor shooting her at least eight times.

To those rising up and speaking out marching and protesting demanding accountability and fighting for justice: YOU have caused urgent action in Congress.  I am proud to help introduce the Justice in Policing Act on your behalf. RT to share8⃣things people should know about it ⬇

5⃣Proven to be a highly effective program in other parts of the world—from Germany and Denmark to Singapore and South Korea—direct grants to businesses to keep workers on payroll is overwhelmingly supported by the American public. A recent poll found 79% supporting this proposal.

4⃣The Paycheck Recovery Act will do all of this while covering more than 36 million workers and costing less than what has already been spent on two rounds of Paycheck Protection Program loans which have failed to successfully stabilize unemployment.

3⃣The Act also covers a portion of businesses' operating costs such as rent to ensure they can re-open when the pandemic ends.   And at a time when more than 100000 small businesses have closed it does this without picking winners and losers covering businesses of all sizes.

2⃣HR 6918 is not just an economic recovery plan; it’s a public health plan too. At a time when at least 27 million people have lost health care during #COVID19 this bill also covers the costs of returning workers to their employer-sponsored benefits including health insurance.

While this legislation has some good elements it ultimately does not achieve that. And it fails to match the scale of this crisis. We can and must do better.   We must give people real relief and certainty before this crisis gets worse—because if we fail to do so it will.

The crisis Americans are facing will not end on its own. We must beat the virus. To beat the virus we must keep people home. To keep people home we must make sure they get their paycheck can access their health care and don’t feel pressured to return to work before it’s safe.

In a last second change the bill also threatens the pensions of working people and harms collective bargaining undermining existing pension plans and exposing retirees to greater risks. This at a time when we should be strengthening collective bargaining and worker power!

We know businesses are also facing the awful choice of closing permanently or re-opening before it's safe to do so.   But this bill doesn't do enough to tie funding for states to public health guidelines so businesses don't have to worry about putting their workers in harm's way.

Employers everywhere are watching in horror as the businesses their workers built fall by the wayside and shutter permanently.   But this bill does not provide enough relief to businesses—including small medium & minority-owned businesses—which are the backbone of our economy.

We are in the midst of a pandemic where 27 million have lost their health care joining the 87 million who were already uninsured or underinsured. Now more than ever people need health care.   But this bill does not guarantee affordable and accessible health care for everyone.

5⃣It meets the moment we're in with a solution that matches the scale of this crisis.   That's why it's supported by business owners labor leaders economists major groups across America—and the public.   There's no time to waste. We must pass the #PaycheckGuaranteeAct.

4⃣It would cover more people for a longer period of time and for less money than we’ve spent on PPP.   More than 36 million workers would benefit. And a majority of the benefits would go to workers in the bottom two income quartiles—getting resources to those who need it most.

3⃣It would keep businesses from closing for good while covering expenses like rent. And not just some businesses.   The program would support businesses and nonprofits of all sizes including small & minority-owned businesses—the exact businesses that have been left behind by PPP.

2⃣It would ensure workers can continue receiving health care benefits. If we fail to act it's estimated that up to 35 million Americans will lose their health coverage because of #COVID. (That's also why we need #MedicareForAll! Health care shouldn't be tied to employment.)

Here are5⃣reasons why we need the #PaycheckGuaranteeAct. Take a look and RT to agree.   1⃣It gets millions of workers who have lost their jobs off of unemployment and back on payroll—quickly getting direct support into the hands of workers. And it would be retroactive to March 1.

To know what we are dealing with we need capacity to test everyone. We are making assumptions that you can only transmit if symptomatic but that is now in question according to researchers which makes it even more important to test everyone. 8./

CDC restrictions on testing created bottleneck. But states have also had to triage testing until capacity increases which is what you are seeing now with saying the most vulnerable & public health workers should be the ones tested.

Then to 3rd factor: restrictions on testing. CDC started w/ severe restrictions on testing which was a huge mistake and partly due to limited kits and inability to process tests & partly due to Trump's refusal to accept the science of #COVID19.  6./

Then you get to 2nd factor which is lab capacity to process the tests. Meaningless to talk about # of tests available if they can't be processed. Lab capacity different in every single state & we need commercial labs processing for more capacity.  5./

But we still don't have enough actual tests at this moment. VP Pence announced today that 1.9 million tests will be available on Monday which will be critical progress if it happens. Remember too that each person requires 2-3 test samples. 4./

Instead of using WHO test that was already developed CDC decided to develop our own. Delayed testing substantially esp when CDC tests were flawed initially. #WA state worked quickly to establish instate testing & also set up lab at #UW which helped tremendously. 3./

To understand why testing is so limited here there are 3 factors: 1) the availability of tests; 2) the ability to process tests; and 3) the restrictions that have been placed on testing either from the federal or state levels. 2./
